description: From Middle English proven, from Old English prōfian (“to esteem, regard as, evince, try, prove”) and Old French prover (“to prove”), both from Latin probō (“test, try, examine, approve, show to be good or fit, prove”, verb), from probus (“good, worthy, excellent”), from Proto-Indo-European *pro-bʰuH-s (“being in front, prominent”), from *pro-, *per- (“toward”) + *bʰuH- (“to be”). Displaced native Middle English sothen (“to prove”), from Old English sōþian (“to prove”). More at for, be, soothe.

examples: You may also need to think about what the prove is doing to the loaf of bread — it is warming the dough and making it moist, allowing it to rise  […]

verbs.description: prove (third-person singular simple present proves, present participle proving, simple past proved, past participle proved or proven)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To demonstrate that something is true or viable; to give proof for.
examples: I will prove that my method is more effective than yours.
It proved to be a cold day.
This battle did not take place in the streets. It took place entirely in words, and it was to prove the turning point in the war.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put to the test, to make trial of.
examples: They took the experimental car to the proving-grounds.
The hypothesis has not been proven to our satisfaction.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ascertain or establish the genuineness or validity of; to verify.
(printing, dated, transitive) To take a trial impression of; to take a proof of.
Alternative form of proof (“allow (dough) to rise; test the activeness of (yeast); pressure-test (a firearm)”)
(homeopathy) To determine by experiment which effects a substance causes when ingested.

description: Simple past form of proove, conjugated as a Germanic strong verb, on the pattern of choose → chose.
